posts.title: [JOB OFFER] Optimize CSS
posts.content:
We're looking for someone who is interested in optimizing our style sheets. Our current situation:

  • Modified version of Bootstrap 3.1.0

  • Theme CSS with redundant and messy code.

  • Another theme CSS with quick fixes and more ugly code.

We would like to move to the following:

  • Unmodified version of Bootstrap 3.1.1

  • A single theme CSS file.

Your job would consist of removing all redundant CSS and organizing it in such a way that it's both logical and easy to change/add things. We'll provide you with the un-minified CSS styles and a collection of static pages. Should there be anything else you need, we'll try to provide it to the best of our abilities.

Send applications directly to me in PM and I'll shortlist the best candidates for consideration by current staff. Please indicate any previous experience with HTML/CSS and include any ideas you have.

Pay negotiable.

posts.signature: PGP: http://k5zq47j6wd3wdvjq.onion/profile/5/pgp

posts.title: Re: Users who bought this listing
posts.content:
What you said is already happening Gold. Your feedbacks are not anonymous. If you leave a feedback, they can see what you bought and who you are.

Instating a public buyer record system could be a good idea in some ways - the buyers can see the best selling items and help them decide which one to go for, and you can determine if the seller is active by looking at the time of his last successful transaction. But also, as a service provider myself, I am very serious about protecting my client's privacy. By default, I assume they don't wish to be known to be using my services. Some customers appreciate this, while others don't really mind. But it's always better safe than sorry.

My suggestion: Only shows a total sales of a listing and offer the buyers an option to buy anonymously. If the buyer picks the option at checkout, only the seller would know their identity. Their feedbacks would be anonymous. If not, then everything would just show as normal.

fnu

posts.title: Re: New Vendor Bond
posts.content:
Kind of hard to say if that is to long, all depends on what you're selling and how much money you're making.  I assume this is to just stop scammers from generating lots of vendor accounts.

I like this bond but only if you also disable all BTC withdrawls from the vendor account for 30 days starting from his first sale. This stops any of them from snagging someone by breaking FE rules. Scammers will never get any BTC out and also lose their bond.

Also, I think you guys should go hardcore on FE rule breakers.  No warning, just instant ban; if they can't read, they shouldn't be a vendor.

posts.title: Re: New Vendor Bond
posts.content:
I'm sort of new here and have made a few purchases.  I figured I'd throw in an idea, but the implementation might take a little extra work.

Make these bonds voluntary and in whatever amount that the seller wants AND make their current bond amounts KNOWN to the buyers.  Maybe put their bond amount right next to the feedback score.

If sellers don't want to do a bond and have no feedback, that would be a huge red flag to me and I wouldn't do business with them.  However, if there was a new seller who voluntarily placed a bond here, and that bond was significantly bigger than the amount of money that I was going to send him, then I would feel secure about it.
Furthermore, sellers that have enough positive feedback wouldn't really need bonds because their feedback speaks for them.

This, in a way, makes their bonds a flexible supplement to their feedback to give the buyer a sense of security and increase their sales.  I say flexible meaning that as their popularity (via good feedback) increases, they could pull back some of their bond, relying more on feedback to generate trust.  Or could even increase their bond amount if business is slow due to low or poor feedback.

I would also make the bonds refundable at any point in time, however from the time that the seller requests their bond back, all their current orders must be concluded before their funds are released.

I think this would be a good way to make things a little more fair for the sellers.  Smaller infrequent sellers can put up a bond twice the amount of any of their listings and when their product runs out and there's no disputes, they can quickly reclaim their bond.  Bigger and better supplied sellers can quickly earn enough trust, eliminating their need for bonds.  Win win for buyers and sellers...... lose for the programmer

Anyway, just and idea, from a buyer only perspective.

Last edited by odsr (2014-07-21 04:42:24)

posts.title: Re: New Vendor Bond
posts.content:
I didn't think twice about the deposit after buying here a few times. Even if the site is compromised, evo run off with the money (unlikely!) or whatever happens you've paid 0.5 to sell whatever you want! Compare that to the sort of fees and commissions in any other business and it is still low.

As for the comments about setting it in dollars. Two points.

1. We are supposed to be promoting bitcoin and since it's the only currency in use here why show it any other way?

2. US Dollars are not the only currency! Believe it or not others exist outside of the USA, Perhaps evo should set the deposit in every known currency? Except that would take forever and some of those are no more stable! I am including the dollar, gb pound and the Euro in that. The difference is their value changes without you even knowing, the money in your pocket can simply be devalued by the government that is in control of your currency.

Just keep things the way they are. The comment about making a limit of a month for vendors to withdraw can only have been made by buyers. 14 days is long enough, otherwise you are doing an ebay and pushing out the little guy who needs to pay bills and allowing the bigger "businesses" to monopolize.

Rant over.

posts.title: US man posts his wanted photo on Facebook, arrested
posts.content:
Read the story of this stupid guy......lmfao...!!!!

(Link:-http://www.**tv.com/article/offbeat/us-man-posts-his-wanted-photo-on-facebook-arrested-475681?pfrom=home-specialevent).

Updated: January 26, 2014 21:15



Washington:  A wanted man in the US who unwittingly shared a police department's mugshot of himself on Facebook was nabbed less than an hour later.

Anthony James Lescowitch Jr had been evading arrest in Pennsylvania since November last year.

The Freeland Police Department posted a photo of Lescowitch on its Facebook page last Monday, noting that Lescowitch, 35, was wanted for aggravated assault and numerous other charges.

The post asked that anyone knowing Lescowitch's whereabouts to call police or 911.

Police said they noticed Lescowitch shared their post about him on his Facebook page minutes after they posted it on theirs, and he mocked police in his post as well, Timesleader.com reported.

An undercover officer used a Facebook profile of a fictitious attractive woman to engage in online conversation with Lescowitch for about a half hour, to gather key information about him.

Lescowitch agreed to meet up with the undercover officer for a cigarette.

When the suspect arrived at the specified location, he was met by the police and arrested.



What do you think...isn't that a stupid idea...????

I think reviewss should usually come after success ( in this case, coins hitting wallet ). It's simply too easy to be wooed by potential positives. Unfortunately with any guide or method you should be in the habit of finding flaw, or incorrect information. Once this has been completed you should move on to a full beginning to end trial, and expect positive ( and completed ) results. Multiple trials is obviously best to show a win/lose ratio if necessary.

Vouching for a method you have not actually completed ( despite where the fault lies - which is no excuse ) is very unpro. Let's skip the buddy buddy stuff guys, and stick to brass tacks, please.

These are just a very few basic things that should be undertaken for reviews, and even moreso vouches. I would expect you to receive a much higher level of paying customers as well OP.

Preview: Authorities have arrested two men for allegedly scheming to sell $1 million worth of bitcoins to anonymous drug buyers using the now-shuttered online drug exchange Silk Road.

In a 27-page complaint filed Friday and made public on Monday, authorities accused Robert Faiella and Charlie Shrem with money laundering and other charges related to facilitating illegal activity on Silk Road.

Silk Road, created in 2011, served as an anonymous online marketplace for illegal products and services including drugs. The FBI shut down the site in early October 2013, calling it “the most sophisticated and extensive criminal marketplace on the Internet today.”

Silk Road users could use only the digital currency bitcoin, which is difficult to trace. That’s where Faiella and Shrem allegedly came in, according to the complaint.

According to the attorney’s office, Faiella ran a bitcoin exchange on the Silk Road site from about December 2011 to October 2013. Faiella allegedly took bitcoin orders from Silk Road users and filled the order through a company called BitInstant -- which, for a fee, lets customers exchange cash for bitcoin anonymously...

Wait several months before doing anything. Why? Plausible deniability. If you were to lash out right now and slash his tires, damage his property, damage his reputation, or hurt him, the finger will be pointed at you first. Let time pass.

After you have waited an appropriate amount of time, it's time to strike back (metaphorically). A physical retaliation is foolish and high risk. Bruises fade, however damage to the reputation and to the mind last forever.
Plant drugs on his property. Card things in his name like dildos and BDSM equipment, and have it sent to his mother's/girlfriend's address. Send photoshopped pictures showing him engaging in illegal activities to his friends, family, and to his employer (engaging in pedophilia, using drugs, or other damaging material).

If you want to create complete unrest in his life, then send minor inconveniences his way as well. Mysterious phone calls at late hours of the night, minor property damage, and anything else that's plausibly deniable.

First off, most of this will quickly be shown to be someone messing with him, and rather than fucking up his life, people will feel bad for him and want to help him out because some asshole is messing with him. Second, once he realizes he is being fucked with he'll start going through the possible names, and even if it is years later, will eventually come around to your name. Third, rather than wear them down, they'll get pissed off, angry and defiant. If someone thinks it is just bad luck/their own fuckups screwing them over, they get depressed. If someone knows someone is fucking with them, they get angry, work harder and will do anything they can to find the SOB doing it.

I'm not going to give anyone specific ideas, but you get the point. In my opinion, if someone has done something bad enough to warrant the time and effort of revenge it should be calculated, patient, devastating and SILENT.

posts.title: Re: when caught by the police, what is a very good excuse to say?
posts.content:
honestly getting anything sent to your house is not a smart idea.  At the very least it will become a ongoing headache. For example depending on the country unless they find the merchandise at your place or can prove that a computer/device/account in your possession was used in the carding process then you have what they call "Reasonable Doubt"; especially if you don't have any prior convictions.  If your local DA is a hard ass they could decide to fuck with you by charging you and putting you through the paces hoping that maybe you will crack and strike a deal. It a favorite tactic by LE, knowing that most people are terrified of prison and will just break down after a enough pressure is applied.

With all that being said I still wouldn't recommend you put yourself in that predicament but if you find your self sitting in an unbearably cold interrogation room just remember to DENY DENY DENY.  If they could lock you up for receiving a fraudulent package without proof you were involed then everyone who's residence was used as a drop would be sitting in prison.... Not to mention it would be alot easier to get rid of my less than desirable neighbors.

posts.title: Re: when caught by the police, what is a very good excuse to say?
posts.content:
"The items are now in the local courier and need to pick it up" It is simple, DONT PICK THEM UP. Refuse the packages, REGARDLESS of the face of courier. The courier could be compelled to play along. Even if you refuse them though, if any complaints are filed, you would now be on the LEOs radar and they could remember your name if comes up again in 6 months to a year later. Oh ya, also completely wipe your harddrives by doing something like DBAN wipes or a dd copy of /dev/urandom in case your computer is ever seized. Then possibly consider a new career. I'd suggest pumping gas, but I'm concerned about your competency around such a flammable liquid. Stocking shelves may be a good fit for you. I know I'm being a bit of a dick, but seriously, you're not going to get away with that for long, assuming you're not a troll.

posts.title: Re: TOR may not protect you from NSA
posts.content:
Tor and Onion routing were actively developed by the Navy.  Two admins went on to work for the NSA.  I've posted this before in another thread--

http://cryptome.org/0004/tor-is-tor.htm

--

28 May 2011

Onion Routing Not Tor Is a Lie

A sends:

Contrary to claims of some Tor Project developers, Tor -- the software itself -- was indeed actively developed by the US Navy.

Check for yourself from a Linux command-line:

$ git clone git://git.torproject.org/tor.git
$ cd tor
$ git log | grep navy.mil | uniq -c
     46 Author: Paul Syverson <syverson@itd.nrl.navy.mil>
     15 Author: Bruce Montrose <montrose@itd.nrl.navy.mil>
See also:

https://gitweb.torproject.org/tor.git/search?s=Paul+Syverson;st=author
https://gitweb.torproject.org/tor.git/search?s=Bruce+Montrose;st=author

46 revisions to the software were made by Paul Syverson while he was working for the Navy, 15 revisions were by Bruce Montrose, also working for the Navy at the same lab.

Another tidbit: Matthew J. Edman also was once a Tor developer. He worked for the Navy too, as a graduate student under supervision of Syverson. He went on to work for NSA, among others.

Roger Dingledine (the lead Tor developer) also once worked for NSA.

The idea that onion routing as a concept is somehow independent from Tor is a lie. The two are one and the same and were developed in harmony.

    Bruce Schneier   
   
he is probably the foremost expert in the world on TOR security
   
   


    News
    World news
    NSA

NSA surveillance: A guide to staying secure
The NSA has huge capabilities – and if it wants in to your computer, it's in. With that in mind, here are five ways to stay safe

• Explaining the latest NSA revelations – Q&A

    Share
    Tweet this
    Email

    Bruce Schneier
        Bruce Schneier   
        theguardian.com, Friday 6 September 2013 09.09 EDT   
        Jump to comments (…)

A patron works on his laptop during the Tech Crunch Disrupt conference in San Francisco, California, September 11.
'Trust the math. Encryption is your friend. That's how you can remain secure even in the face of the NSA.' Photograph: Beck Diefenbach/Reuters

Now that we have enough details about how the NSA eavesdrops on the internet, including today's disclosures of the NSA's deliberate weakening of cryptographic systems, we can finally start to figure out how to protect ourselves.

For the past two weeks, I have been working with the Guardian on NSA stories, and have read hundreds of top-secret NSA documents provided by whistleblower Edward Snowden. I wasn't part of today's story – it was in process well before I showed up – but everything I read confirms what the Guardian is reporting.

At this point, I feel I can provide some advice for keeping secure against such an adversary.

The primary way the NSA eavesdrops on internet communications is in the network. That's where their capabilities best scale. They have invested in enormous programs to automatically collect and analyze network traffic. Anything that requires them to attack individual endpoint computers is significantly more costly and risky for them, and they will do those things carefully and sparingly.

Leveraging its secret agreements with telecommunications companies – all the US and UK ones, and many other "partners" around the world – the NSA gets access to the communications trunks that move internet traffic. In cases where it doesn't have that sort of friendly access, it does its best to surreptitiously monitor communications channels: tapping undersea cables, intercepting satellite communications, and so on.

That's an enormous amount of data, and the NSA has equivalently enormous capabilities to quickly sift through it all, looking for interesting traffic. "Interesting" can be defined in many ways: by the source, the destination, the content, the individuals involved, and so on. This data is funneled into the vast NSA system for future analysis.

The NSA collects much more metadata about internet traffic: who is talking to whom, when, how much, and by what mode of communication. Metadata is a lot easier to store and analyze than content. It can be extremely personal to the individual, and is enormously valuable intelligence.

The Systems Intelligence Directorate is in charge of data collection, and the resources it devotes to this is staggering. I read status report after status report about these programs, discussing capabilities, operational details, planned upgrades, and so on. Each individual problem – recovering electronic signals from fiber, keeping up with the terabyte streams as they go by, filtering out the interesting stuff – has its own group dedicated to solving it. Its reach is global.

The NSA also attacks network devices directly: routers, switches, firewalls, etc. Most of these devices have surveillance capabilities already built in; the trick is to surreptitiously turn them on. This is an especially fruitful avenue of attack; routers are updated less frequently, tend not to have security software installed on them, and are generally ignored as a vulnerability.

The NSA also devotes considerable resources to attacking endpoint computers. This kind of thing is done by its TAO – Tailored Access Operations – group. TAO has a menu of exploits it can serve up against your computer – whether you're running Windows, Mac OS, Linux, iOS, or something else – and a variety of tricks to get them on to your computer. Your anti-virus software won't detect them, and you'd have trouble finding them even if you knew where to look. These are hacker tools designed by hackers with an essentially unlimited budget. What I took away from reading the Snowden documents was that if the NSA wants in to your computer, it's in. Period.

The NSA deals with any encrypted data it encounters more by subverting the underlying cryptography than by leveraging any secret mathematical breakthroughs. First, there's a lot of bad cryptography out there. If it finds an internet connection protected by MS-CHAP, for example, that's easy to break and recover the key. It exploits poorly chosen user passwords, using the same dictionary attacks hackers use in the unclassified world.

As was revealed today, the NSA also works with security product vendors to ensure that commercial encryption products are broken in secret ways that only it knows about. We know this has happened historically: CryptoAG and Lotus Notes are the most public examples, and there is evidence of a back door in Windows. A few people have told me some recent stories about their experiences, and I plan to write about them soon. Basically, the NSA asks companies to subtly change their products in undetectable ways: making the random number generator less random, leaking the key somehow, adding a common exponent to a public-key exchange protocol, and so on. If the back door is discovered, it's explained away as a mistake. And as we now know, the NSA has enjoyed enormous success from this program.

TAO also hacks into computers to recover long-term keys. So if you're running a VPN that uses a complex shared secret to protect your data and the NSA decides it cares, it might try to steal that secret. This kind of thing is only done against high-value targets.

How do you communicate securely against such an adversary? Snowden said it in an online Q&A soon after he made his first document public: "Encryption works. Properly implemented strong crypto systems are one of the few things that you can rely on."

I believe this is true, despite today's revelations and tantalizing hints of "groundbreaking cryptanalytic capabilities" made by James Clapper, the director of national intelligence in another top-secret document. Those capabilities involve deliberately weakening the cryptography.

Snowden's follow-on sentence is equally important: "Unfortunately, endpoint security is so terrifically weak that NSA can frequently find ways around it."

Endpoint means the software you're using, the computer you're using it on, and the local network you're using it in. If the NSA can modify the encryption algorithm or drop a Trojan on your computer, all the cryptography in the world doesn't matter at all. If you want to remain secure against the NSA, you need to do your best to ensure that the encryption can operate unimpeded.

With all this in mind, I have five pieces of advice:

1) Hide in the network. Implement hidden services. Use Tor to anonymize yourself. Yes, the NSA targets Tor users, but it's work for them. The less obvious you are, the safer you are.

2) Encrypt your communications. Use TLS. Use IPsec. Again, while it's true that the NSA targets encrypted connections – and it may have explicit exploits against these protocols – you're much better protected than if you communicate in the clear.

3) Assume that while your computer can be compromised, it would take work and risk on the part of the NSA – so it probably isn't. If you have something really important, use an air gap. Since I started working with the Snowden documents, I bought a new computer that has never been connected to the internet. If I want to transfer a file, I encrypt the file on the secure computer and walk it over to my internet computer, using a USB stick. To decrypt something, I reverse the process. This might not be bulletproof, but it's pretty good.

4) Be suspicious of commercial encryption software, especially from large vendors. My guess is that most encryption products from large US companies have NSA-friendly back doors, and many foreign ones probably do as well. It's prudent to assume that foreign products also have foreign-installed backdoors. Closed-source software is easier for the NSA to backdoor than open-source software. Systems relying on master secrets are vulnerable to the NSA, through either legal or more clandestine means.

5) Try to use public-domain encryption that has to be compatible with other implementations. For example, it's harder for the NSA to backdoor TLS than BitLocker, because any vendor's TLS has to be compatible with every other vendor's TLS, while BitLocker only has to be compatible with itself, giving the NSA a lot more freedom to make changes. And because BitLocker is proprietary, it's far less likely those changes will be discovered. Prefer symmetric cryptography over public-key cryptography. Prefer conventional discrete-log-based systems over elliptic-curve systems; the latter have constants that the NSA influences when they can.

Since I started working with Snowden's documents, I have been using GPG, Silent Circle, Tails, OTR, TrueCrypt, BleachBit, and a few other things I'm not going to write about. There's an undocumented encryption feature in my Password Safe program from the command line); I've been using that as well.

I understand that most of this is impossible for the typical internet user. Even I don't use all these tools for most everything I am working on. And I'm still primarily on Windows, unfortunately. Linux would be safer.

The NSA has turned the fabric of the internet into a vast surveillance platform, but they are not magical. They're limited by the same economic realities as the rest of us, and our best defense is to make surveillance of us as expensive as possible.

Trust the math. Encryption is your friend. Use it well, and do your best to ensure that nothing can compromise it. That's how you can remain secure even in the face of the NSA.

posts.content:
I have dealt with this seller for several months now on Agora Marketplace. I have never had an issue with him, and the cocaine is by far the best for the price.

I use the coke personally and find it to be of a perfect level of quality for a night out. A very nice buzz. Not too overpowering, but just enough to make you chat shit and knock back the pints like an animal. Although it is worth noting that I am generally not a fan of 'pure' coke. I don't like being too wired and not being able to sleep. If you're into getting wired off your tits then this gear ain't for you. It is very much 'social' cocaine.

I have had coke from LegalEyez (although it's been proven that it contains no coke) and can say that FerrariBlacks gear is way better. I don't know why anyone would order from LegalEyez when you can get this stuff for the same price!

I also used to order quite regularly from ToYouTeam. Since ordering FB's stuff I have not ordered from TYT. The quality is near enough on par, maybe very slightly worse, but for the price it's worth it.

I sell this gear on for £30/g to my friends and they've never complained. I have sold it on to people I don't know for £40/g easy.

Delivery has ALWAYS been next day in UK.

Stealth is your standard vac sealed bag in a padded envelope.

I will continue to order from FB for as long as he is selling. Even if I decided I wanted to do better coke myself I would still stock up to resell as I am making an extra couple hundred quid a month.

Quality - 9/10 (as 'Social' Coke)
Delivery - 10/10 (Next Day UK, every time)

posts.title: Re: FerrariBlack Cocaine Thread Review and Questions UK to Worldwide
posts.content:
Hi all

Ok I have sampled a few different deliveries from these guys over a period of weeks. Mainly the basic good quality but also little of the fish-scale quality. I have done the same with the most popular 3 other of the UK and NL vendors that I won't name here. They are all very different in their approach and all have merits.

I do not use EZ testers much because they can be fooled and even if they indicated good amounts of Cocaine HCL they do not tell you what the adulterants are. It is far more important to know what adulterants are in there than the absolute purity. E.g. Give me a bag of 1g Cocaine HCl of even just 20% purity as long as it is just cut with inert adulterants then I'm a happy man. Give me 60% purity and cut with shite to make it feel purer then I get pissed off.

What I can say about these guys is their core, high quality fish-scale supply is good and clean from source. Not too much shit in from source so you get a really nice euphoric high from it. It can be cleaned up (there are various washes) and it is that is something I would do to improve it more but as it is, for the price it is very good. Washing this stuff is just for old gits like me who think the 80's were the only time you could get good gear.

Their basic stuff is based in the clean core fish-scale but cut down (as you'd expect for the lower cost!). Bit the thing is that it seems to be cut down with inert adulterants so you don't spoil the high. I haven't detected any amphetamines, ephedrine, speeds etc. only some left over crap from the original production (before import) which is easily washed out. There are a lot of vendors out there selling similar purity but with nasty shit cut in.

So, what I'm trying to say is this.

You buy a basic good quality g of C from these guys and you are getting reasonable purity that is not cut with shit that will ruin your high. You get the purity you pay for and an honesty about what they cut with which is very, very cool.

I will order again and I hope they stay safe, secure and do not let their quality, security or principles slip.

Horrifying revelations....



James Glanz, Jeff Larson and Andrew W. Lehren, The New York Times | Updated: January 28, 2014


When a smartphone user opens Angry Birds, the popular game application, and starts slinging birds at chortling green pigs, spies could be lurking in the background to snatch data revealing the player's location, age, sex and other personal information, according to secret British intelligence documents.

In their globe-spanning surveillance for terrorism suspects and other targets, the National Security Agency and its British counterpart have been trying to exploit a basic byproduct of modern telecommunications: With each new generation of mobile phone technology, ever greater amounts of personal data pour onto networks where spies can pick it up.

According to dozens of previously undisclosed classified documents, among the most valuable of those unintended intelligence tools are so-called leaky apps that spew everything from the smartphone identification codes of users to where they have been that day.

The NSA and Britain's Government Communications Headquarters were working together on how to collect and store data from dozens of smartphone apps by 2007, according to the documents, provided by Edward J. Snowden, the former NSA contractor. Since then, the agencies have traded recipes for grabbing location and planning data when a target uses Google Maps, and for vacuuming up address books, buddy lists, telephone logs and the geographic data embedded in photographs when someone sends a post to the mobile versions of Facebook, Flickr, LinkedIn, Twitter and other Internet services.

The eavesdroppers' pursuit of mobile networks has been outlined in earlier reports, but the secret documents, shared by The New York Times, The Guardian and ProPublica, offer far more details of their ambitions for smartphones and the apps that run on them. The efforts were part of an initiative called "the mobile surge," according to a 2011 British document, an analogy to the troop surges in Iraq and Afghanistan. One NSA analyst's enthusiasm was evident in the breathless title - "Golden Nugget!" - given to one slide for a top-secret 2010 talk that described iPhones and Android phones as rich resources, another document noted.

The scale and the specifics of the data haul are not clear. The documents show that the NSA and the British agency routinely obtain information from certain apps, particularly some of those introduced earliest to cellphones. With some newer apps, including Angry Birds, the agencies have a similar capability, the documents show, but they do not make explicit whether the spies have put that into practice. Some personal data, developed in profiles by advertising companies, could be particularly sensitive: A secret 2012 British intelligence document says that spies can scrub smartphone apps to collect details like a user's "political alignment" and sexual orientation.

posts.title: Re: Gift Card Cardable Site
posts.content:
Havent carded egift cards in quite a long time, but some places I used to do that I didn't notice anyone else doing:

1. Loccitane.com ( High end french boutique chain in US and EU instant egift cards sent via email ) Increments of $200 I think, sell CRAZY fast on CL 70% np. Girls eat these up if you live in / near major cities in US/EU, but for other countries they can be used online. I've found these lasted longer than the rest. I haven't tested these in a year atleast though, lol. Great way to make some side cash for beginners, with bonus of meeting hotties consistently ( not in your hometown or using your real # of course, and if you keep doing it in same area someone will sting youre ass, lol ), but if youre a mobile instore guy this is a great way to make a few k straight to your hotel the few days before you leave for the next city. Always test a few by buying some on a few different days spread out then checking the balances 1,2,3,4,5,6 etc days out to see how long they last. You dont want to play with fire selling gcs from your hotel area 3 days before you leave if they go bad in 24 hours, lol =P

2. LordandTaylor.com  I used to kill these guys, lol. Nice clothes, shoes, cologne, hygiene stuff, suits, great instore selection with auto readers posted on pillars away from counters so you can scan your egift cards before you check out to verify they're still good ( meant to check balance, will say 0$ if its been cancelled ). Their fraud dept was still pretty shitty about a year ago, I imagine its the same. Could card from same ip to different emails, over and over, and over. Today you'd probably want to play it smart with some easy basics, vpn, socks (cc city/state), bleachbit when done, rinse, repeat ) I've only tried uS cvv.

3. TheLimited.com Clothing store for women, not even sure theyre still around because this one was atleast two years ago. Suprisingly I remember these selling well on CL. I took my gf there one time and she hated it, but they had their store right next to a gucci store in a plaza mall with nothing but high end retailers from side to side. She said nothing was "branded" that she could recognize, it all felt like cheap material, and reminded her of old secretaries or librarian clothing, lol. Whatever, if they sell they sell =P

These are all common sense, but just incase, food etc:

Sonic
Dunkin Donuts
Starbucks
Caribou Coffee
Jack in the box

Again its been like a year or two atleast since I've used these, so test before taking my word =P I'm sure I have more egift card places I'll have to think on. I havent carded online in years haha.

Cool thread, stuff like this is great. I loved when I first started and people would share little shit like this here and there.

posts.title: Money
posts.content:
Hi,

I am completely new to TOR. I saw the market. Very much interested in Paypal. So if buy one account, can i immediately use it to purchase it. i want to buy a apple mac. saw it for just 500$ in TOR. why no one is selling apple here? why are there accounts with no balances? who would buy them and why?

posts.title: Re: Money
posts.content:
id advice you not try to move founds from hacked paypal accs, they lately increased security even more, success rate is low. even if you have best setup possible theres also another issue, the vendor checks the balance, which means that shows on theyr fraud radar, after victim used a specific OS/Browser/IP for a long time, then suddenly new setup log in for a few secs to check balance and then after a while ...another new setup (you the buyer) which creates a predictable pattern for them.

until i find a vendor who doesn't check the balance and also operates a phishing site and will offer me info like what browser/os/screen resolution/cookies maybe/etc did the victim use...im gonna try card it instead

posts.title: Re: Money
posts.content:
You want to buy a PayPal account to purchase physical items?

If so, you need to do some research first. PayPal is extremely strong in terms of fraud preventative security, it'll take you a lot of time and money to become familiar with account behavior. Not only this, but what if the original owner has SMS notifications or email on there phone, the payment will get charged back and it's game over for that account, money wasted. Also, you'd need a drop address as paypal records the shipping address entered in orders.

People mainly buy fresh paypal accounts with no balance in order to launder money, but there's tons of other reasons.

posts.title: Re: Money
posts.content:
First, do some research on PayPal. When you buy an account from any vendor, check the owners address, then match your Socks proxy nearer to them. After you login, do not cash out or buy anything immediately. Go through transaction history. Note the size of funds the owner transfers. Note whether he is sending money to other accounts often or is he buying anything. Now match your activities to the owner and try to be legit.
Zero balance accounts are used for cashing out or as middleman account. This is used to extend the time of getting a charge back and giving you the time to cash out. And one last thing no one will sell Apple Mac for 500$. If you saw an ad in the deep web, it is just a scam.

Last edited by monkey (2014-01-28 18:52:02)

posts.title: postal money order method
posts.content:
This guide covers one method I used to use for postal money orders. Postal money orders are super easy to cash at any post office with a fake id if you're mobile / have cashiers, but can be laundered easily as well. Victims feel safe paying with them because of some inherint trust they hold with the US post office, lol. It couldn't be further from the truth.
It can take up to 45 days to get any kind of investigation underway, and the likliehood of you triggering an investigation using this is slim.

This is a great side hustle to have in your inventory because it requires virtually no setup time ( 15 minutes ) and after that it's an autopilot extra
few k a week. This will yield 5-10 money orders ranging from $700-$1500 a week for very part timers.

This is a method meant for instore crews, and fraudsters who generally already go through a steady supply of ids for other needs. This will squeeze out another few k a week out of things you were likely finished with. I used this country wide while instoring as a way to cover my travel expenses so everything was profit in a sense. However the cost to profit ratio is plenty fine enough to do it as a stand alone and would be reasonible to buy fake ids specifically for this.


What you'll need:

Email account
Fake ID
Visa or MC gc that requires no online activation and holds no avs ( or nonavs cvv )
Drop address


1. Register on www.gunauction.com and www.gunbroker.com as sellers.
( USE same information, same card, same drop, email on both )

2. Google and Bing your way through firearm listings to find what you're going to be "selling".
( Copy what you see, pics, description, etc. Go back to the websites mentioned where you're a registered seller and post your finds. I prefer to keep to
assault rifles, and antiques at 60% of value. Be sure to mention you're only method of payment is through a Secure US Postal Money Order, this will raise no red flags. )

3. Once you have about 10 listings ( 5 each on both sites ) sit back and wait for your auctions to buy out. If you have placed them appropriately someone will buy now
at your crazy low price! The target crowd here doesn't need a bunch of hand holding and assurances, lol.  When the winners email you be sure to email them with a response similar too:

Ex. Hello,

       Noticed you bought my listing. You got a great buy there, at a very good deal. I hope it's going to a good home, lol
     Below is my address and where your firearm will be shipping from. Please be informed as per my auction that I only accept Postal money orders. I've had
too many bad experiences with Western Union money orders and cashiers checks. If you could forward your FFL along with payment to:

Johnny B Good
123 Fake Street
wintertown, Sahara
0000000

Once I've received your FFL and payment and I'll notify you with tracking as soon as it's shipped.

Thanks, Johnny


** FYI: Many of your victims will be or claim to be LE. It's just a fact, especially when buying/selling firearms legally online ( a big % of those guys are LE in their real lives ). Don't shite your britches when you get crazy emails, lol. They're just upset =P You should be burning and working accounts fast enough to where you don't speak with these guys again anyway **

*** My posts and advice, and views are generally aimed toward those with a high mobility life style. I would never recommend using the things I talk about if you're some small town guy that's looking to "break in" on something***

**** There are a ton of ways to launder these things simply. I'm not going to fill in blanks here because honestly it serves as a retard proofing of sorts. If you can't think your way out of "How do these get to $$$$$?" this is the wrong thread for you =P ****

P.S I've cashed postal money orders from different states, while in a different state, using an out of state fake id with absolutely no issues in a lot of US states. From the little cow poke post offices in tinytown, usa to major metro post offices. $700 to $1500 no problem. If the office is small its good to call ahead and ask they can cash a postal mo for xxxx amount of dollars.

Last edited by lolwhat (2014-01-28 18:26:23)

posts.title: Re: Counterfeiting money - Share you're knowledge
posts.content:
jack's guide isn't worthless like the powder glass thing is an interesting idea that i would of never thought of

but the 100% cotton paper doesnt pass the pen test nor does it feel much like usd at all unless you add shit to it, and last time i was at walmart they didn't have a watermark on the 100% cotton sheets

i have no idea where he gets the concept you can print the watermark and strip lightly on the back or whatever. ive tried that before and in order for the watermark/strip to be visible when held up to the light you have to print it quite dark, and too light and you don't see anything

the 2 sheet method involves newsprint which is kinda shitty but ok for a home small operation. the notes come out like 30% thicker then real ones and the paper is not designed for printing so it isnt as crisp as regular paper. plus the notes will be darker and also darker when held up to the light

those photo printers are pretty dumb because they take FOREVER to print. the extra dpi is meaningless, dpi is really quite overrated. micro printing is a useless security feature, and color shifting ink is mostly useless and depending on what you want to do often not worth the extra effort to make

there's only 1 way i know how to print the watermark/security thread on one sheet of paper and it only works with inkjet printers and im much more a fan of lasers so idk. you have inkjet printers like the hp officejet pro x series that can print 70 pages a minute (probably more like 20-30 with hi-res bills, which is still great) but hp is the worst brand ever. canon is the best but they're slow

also watermark ink is readily available everywhere i just havent tried it yet. i think it could work but it wouldn't produce a very good security thread, probably not that important for 20s and under though. the idea of watermark ink is to be transculent and be just slightly darker then the paper

if i had a big printing press id probably consider the 2 sheet method because the ink wouldnt be dull like it is with inkjets and you could soak the notes in water and smash them with a huge roller to help with the slight additional thickness. the feel of newsprint isnt atrocious especially after you age the notes so to speak

posts.title: Re: Counterfeiting money - Share you're knowledge
posts.content:
I haven't tried the powdered glass thing either but he is so clueless on the other crap (ie: paper passing the pen test), that I am going to assume he has never done the glass thing either; it just sounds good on paper (maybe?)

I personally went through several canon inkjet printers and found they all have alignment issues; was very fustrating. And yeah, you only need 1200x1200 (2400 dpi); again he talks about needing this expensive scanner. Hell, even a cheap $50 all-in one will have a scanner that can grab the needed dpi to scan any bill.

As for the newsprint, I tried it as well but ran into the same issues as you with bills becoming to dark and just not printing well. Inkjet needs a really smooth surface to print well, otherwise it just blures to much. The newsprint only passes the pen test because it is 100% recycled; I found some bright white paper that is 100% recycled as well and that passes the pen but there is nothing available in the thickness needed for the 2 sheet method.

I just make my own true cotton rag paper from pulp and externally size it. I can get the paper to about a 45gsm thickness but it falls apart if I try to go any thinner in my mould. Glue these two sheets together and then putting them under 20 tons of pressure on a simple shop press can get them to about the right thickness.

My only issue is my paper seems to be more translucent and the strip and watermark are still a little visible with the 2 sheet method but it is still a lot more manageable than newsprint.

I bought two watermark screenprint inks from different suppliers over in China (I bought two because I wasn't sure if I was going to get scammed or not but both came through).  So what is it?  It works like they say but it was nothing more than white ink/paint but it created a darker image when held to the light.  it is just basically printing a white image on a white piece of paper.  Man did I feel dumb after I used that crap.  Could of did all that for $10 from walmart.

China Man +1
Me: 0

posts.title: Re: Counterfeiting money - Share you're knowledge
posts.content:
It was hell/time consuming to get the right measurement amounts of pulp/water tunned to my mould and deckle.  But once that was done, I turn out large sheets pretty damn fast (takes some practice).  It just sucks the FED uses the dandyroll technique to make watermarks (watermark is darker instead of lighter) otherwise I could just make my watermark when making the paper.

As for the watermark ink, I trashed the stuff months ago. It's literally just white screen print ink that you can find at any hobby store.  Just make sure anything you use is waterbased, otherwise inkjet ink won't adhere to it. (even then it didn't look good).

posts.title: Re: Counterfeiting money - Share you're knowledge
posts.content:
I'd say counterfeiting is kind of a secret trade ^^ I personally only resell, so I've seen alot of different bills. Different security features, different holograms, different types of paper. I can't tell you much about how to make counterfeits, but I can tell you this. What the market needs the most is 1:1 coloring. Whether you are buying CF bills or you are an aspiring counterfeiter: Get the colors right. The feel can be faked, the security measures arent checked much when it looks real from afar and it feels real.

posts.title: Re: Counterfeiting money - Share you're knowledge
posts.content:
you just take 100% cotton paper and use 1 of several techniques to print the watermark/security strip, but make them not visible at face value and only when held up to the light. it's called making layers of ink. offset presses doing it naturally. inkjets don't, so you have to find a way to simulate it which ive done and im sure many others have

actually creating the paper is possible with paper making pulp kits but the equipment needed to put security threads inside the paper is probably hundreds of thousands of dollars
